context: The VOCs identified by Huang et al. were similar to those identified in this study, and the measured concentrations were of similar order of magnitude. The remaining published sewer VOC data is based on liquid phase (sewage) sampling, although as shown by Haas and Herrmann (1996) it is expected that the range of VOCs identified in the sewage will be present in the headspace air. A similar range of VOCs to those identified in this study (Table 3) have been observed during sewage sampling at municipal wastewater treatment plant inlets in Spain (Escalas et al., 2003), Italy (Fatone et al., 2011), and Greece (Nikolaou et al., 2002), with toluene consistently being identified as a dominant VOCs along with trimethylbenzene and m,p-xylene. Halogenated hydrocarbons were also identified in these studies (Escalas et al., 2003; Nikolaou et al., 2002). Given that a similar range of VOCs (and in many cases dominant VOCs) have been identified in sewer headspace air and sewage across diverse countries and climatic regions, the data and conclusions presented in this paper are not restricted to the Australian context and are useful for identifying the odour implications of sewer headspace VOCs for the wider industry. With most 95th percentile VOC concentrations below their associated OTVs, sewer headspace VOCs are unlikely to be a significant contributor to sewer odours.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, Methylsulfanylmethane and toluene are both mentioned as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) identified in studies related to sewage and wastewater treatment. However, the relationship between them is not explicitly discussed, and they are presented as part of a broader analysis of VOCs without any direct interaction or comparative significance highlighted. Toluene is noted as a dominant VOC, but Methylsulfanylmethane's specific role or relevance in relation to toluene is not established.
